title: Fed chair candidate Hassett says U.S behind the curve on lowering rates
description: Hassett said the artificial intelligence boom is boosting economic growth while simultaneously putting downward pressure on inflation.
content:
National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett said Tuesday that the Federal Reserve is not cutting interest rates quickly enough, even as the U.S. economy grew at a much faster pace than expected in the third quarter.

title: Delhi HC protects Sunil Gavaskar’s personality rights
description: Delhi High Court protects former cricketer Sunil Gavaskar’s personality rights, restraining websites from using his name or images without consent. Court also orders removal of obscene content and restrains use of personality traits through artificial intelligence and deepfake technology. Gavaskar’s statement calls it an important recognition of sportsperson’s rights.
content:

title: Delhi HC protects Sunil Gavaskar’s personality rights, orders takedown of objectionable content
description: Justice Manmeet Pritam Singh Arora also restrained several defendants from using Gavaskar's personality traits through artificial intelligence and deepfake technology, and ordered that certain obscene content uploaded on the Internet are taken down.
content:
The high court said the URLs of the offensive material, infringing posts, videos and allied contents should be taken down by the websites within 72 hours and in case of failure, the social media intermediaries concerned should remove the content.

title: White House advisor Hassett says GDP 'fantastic,' job gains to jump

title: NYT reporter sues Google, xAI, OpenAI over chatbot training
description: AN investigative reporter best known for exposing fraud at Silicon Valley blood-testing startup Theranos sued Elon Musk's xAI, Anthropic, Google, OpenAI, Meta Platforms and Perplexity on Monday for using copyrighted books without permission to train their artificial intelligence (AI) systems.

title: Telco now 8.6 percent of GDP; general reaction is ho-hum
description: MANY of the towering intellectuals in the US — even those who can write down mathematical models for complex economic problems in a jiffy or those with a firm grasp of algorithms — still harbor a healthy dose of skepticism towards what the broader world call artificial intelligence or AI. Those in that cohort do not describe AI as it is described in popular literature. They either call it “Large Language Models” (LLM), or “Modern Large Language Models,” or MLLM. A fellow doing research work on AI at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) calls AI “loose grammar engines.”
